IMHO, it should somewhat like Twitter or Twister (except it should *not* be limited to 140 chars). It should be possible to follow and unfollow, and direct/private messages would also be nice.

From the Twister experience I'd say that a â€œfirehoseâ€ (global stream) is necessary, otherwise people will have problem finding somebody to follow.

As an experiment (i.e., I'm unsure if the ZN code likes it) I've added
```json
"license": "Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0)",
```
to [my blog](/kappasigma.bit/)'s `content.json` file.

IMHO, IDs shouldn't be tied to a specific provider. The more providers, the merrier. However, content providers â€” bloggers, moderators, â€¦ â€” should, of course, be allowed to chose which ID providers they accept.

> why not choose to not authenticate at all?

I guess the only excuse I can find is that it allows for fewer duplicate usernames in e.g. a chat.
Having to register also serves a rate-limiting purpose, but that would be better handled by hashcash (the site â€˜ownerâ€™ could require e.g. minimum a 20 bit collision for posting).

In a chat, or in the comments of a blog, it would be nice to be able to refer to something another participant said earlier â€” possibly even on another zite â€” so I would have to see a noname solution in real life before voting for such a solution. But I'm in for anything that works.

[SILC](http://silcnet.org/info.html) can handle duplicate usernames in an otherwise IRC-like environment, so it's not undoable.

I'm not sure legacy hashcash is a solution these days, when people can just throw their GPU or ASIC chip after a PoW-task, but something hashcash-like would be nice. Very few people are using ZeroNet, yet spam is already a problem.

> Adding a LICENCE.txt file (1) inside the ZeroNet site's dir

In that case, such a license should make it clear if there are different terms for the site code and the site contents.

@muja, I disagree that this is overkill. I'm not aware about the license for ZeroBlog, but ZeroNet itself is distributed under GPLv2+, so let's assume ZeroBlog uses the same license â€“ just for the sake of the argument. Putting `{"license": "GPL"}` in content.json in ambiguous at best because nobody knows whether the license covers the software or the contents. And just because the software is GPL'ed, it doesn't follow that the contents should also be GPL'ed.
